AccessPointArn.desc: The unique Amazon Resource Name (ARN) associated with the access point.

AccessPointId.desc: The ID of the access point, assigned by Amazon EFS.

ClientToken.length: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 64.
ClientToken.desc: The opaque string specified in the request to ensure idempotent creation.

FileSystemId.desc: The ID of the EFS file system that the access point applies to.

LifeCycleState.desc: Identifies the lifecycle phase of the access point.

Name.desc: The name of the access point. This is the value of the Name tag.

OwnerId.desc: Identified the AWS account that owns the access point resource.

PosixUser.desc: The full POSIX identity, including the user ID, group ID, and secondary group IDs on the access point that is used for all file operations by NFS clients using the access point.

RootDirectory.desc: The directory on the Amazon EFS file system that the access point exposes as the root directory to NFS clients using the access point.

Tags.desc: The tags associated with the access point, presented as an array of Tag objects.

Status.desc: Describes the status of the file system's backup policy.

OwnerGid.desc: Specifies the POSIX group ID to apply to the RootDirectory. Accepts values from 0 to 2^32 (4294967295).

OwnerUid.desc: Specifies the POSIX user ID to apply to the RootDirectory. Accepts values from 0 to 2^32 (4294967295).

Permissions.desc: Specifies the POSIX permissions to apply to the RootDirectory, in the format of an octal number representing the file's mode bits.

CreationTime.desc: The time that the file system was created, in seconds (since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z).

CreationToken.length: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 64.
CreationToken.desc: The opaque string specified in the request.

Encrypted.desc: A Boolean value that, if true, indicates that the file system is encrypted.

FileSystemArn.desc: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) for the EFS file system, in the format arn:aws:elasticfilesystem:region:account-id:file-system/file-system-id . Example with sample data: arn:aws:elasticfilesystem:us-west-2:1111333322228888:file-system/fs-01234567

FileSystemId.desc: The ID of the file system, assigned by Amazon EFS.

KmsKeyId.desc: The ID of an AWS Key Management Service (AWS KMS) customer master key (CMK) that was used to protect the encrypted file system.

LifeCycleState.desc: The lifecycle phase of the file system.

Name.desc: You can add tags to a file system, including a Name tag. For more information, see CreateFileSystem. If the file system has a Name tag, Amazon EFS returns the value in this field.

NumberOfMountTargets.desc: The current number of mount targets that the file system has. For more information, see CreateMountTarget.

OwnerId.desc: The AWS account that created the file system. If the file system was created by an IAM user, the parent account to which the user belongs is the owner.

PerformanceMode.desc: The performance mode of the file system.

ProvisionedThroughputInMibps.desc: The throughput, measured in MiB/s, that you want to provision for a file system. Valid values are 1-1024. Required if ThroughputMode is set to provisioned. The limit on throughput is 1024 MiB/s. You can get these limits increased by contacting AWS Support. For more information, see Amazon EFS Limits That You Can Increase in the Amazon EFS User Guide.

SizeInBytes.desc: The latest known metered size (in bytes) of data stored in the file system, in its Value field, and the time at which that size was determined in its Timestamp field. The Timestamp value is the integer number of seconds since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z. The SizeInBytes value doesn't represent the size of a consistent snapshot of the file system, but it is eventually consistent when there are no writes to the file system. That is, SizeInBytes represents actual size only if the file system is not modified for a period longer than a couple of hours. Otherwise, the value is not the exact size that the file system was at any point in time.

Tags.desc: The tags associated with the file system, presented as an array of Tag objects.

ThroughputMode.desc: The throughput mode for a file system. There are two throughput modes to choose from for your file system: bursting and provisioned. If you set ThroughputMode to provisioned, you must also set a value for ProvisionedThroughPutInMibps. You can decrease your file system's throughput in Provisioned Throughput mode or change between the throughput modes as long as itâ€™s been more than 24 hours since the last decrease or throughput mode change.

Timestamp.desc: The time at which the size of data, returned in the Value field, was determined. The value is the integer number of seconds since 1970-01-01T00:00:00Z.

Value.desc: The latest known metered size (in bytes) of data stored in the file system.

ValueInIA.desc: The latest known metered size (in bytes) of data stored in the Infrequent Access storage class.

ValueInStandard.desc: The latest known metered size (in bytes) of data stored in the Standard storage class.

TransitionToIA.desc: A value that describes the period of time that a file is not accessed, after which it transitions to the IA storage class. Metadata operations such as listing the contents of a directory don't count as file access events.

AvailabilityZoneId.desc: The unique and consistent identifier of the Availability Zone (AZ) that the mount target resides in. For example, use1-az1 is an AZ ID for the us-east-1 Region and it has the same location in every AWS account.

AvailabilityZoneName.desc: The name of the Availability Zone (AZ) that the mount target resides in. AZs are independently mapped to names for each AWS account. For example, the Availability Zone us-east-1a for your AWS account might not be the same location as us-east-1a for another AWS account.

FileSystemId.desc: The ID of the file system for which the mount target is intended.

IpAddress.length: Minimum length of 7. Maximum length of 15.
IpAddress.desc: Address at which the file system can be mounted by using the mount target.

LifeCycleState.desc: Lifecycle state of the mount target.

MountTargetId.length: Minimum length of 13. Maximum length of 45.

NetworkInterfaceId.desc: The ID of the network interface that Amazon EFS created when it created the mount target.

OwnerId.desc: AWS account ID that owns the resource.

SubnetId.length: Minimum length of 15. Maximum length of 47.
SubnetId.desc: The ID of the mount target's subnet.

VpcId.desc: The Virtual Private Cloud (VPC) ID that the mount target is configured in.

Gid.desc: The POSIX group ID used for all file system operations using this access point.

SecondaryGids.desc: Secondary POSIX group IDs used for all file system operations using this access point.

Uid.desc: The POSIX user ID used for all file system operations using this access point.

CreationInfo.desc: (Optional) Specifies the POSIX IDs and permissions to apply to the access point's RootDirectory. If the RootDirectory > Path specified does not exist, EFS creates the root directory using the CreationInfo settings when a client connects to an access point. When specifying the CreationInfo, you must provide values for all properties.

Path.length: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 100.
Path.desc: Specifies the path on the EFS file system to expose as the root directory to NFS clients using the access point to access the EFS file system. A path can have up to four subdirectories. If the specified path does not exist, you are required to provide the CreationInfo.

Key.length: Minimum length of 1. Maximum length of 128.
Key.desc: The tag key (String). The key can't start with aws:.

Value.desc: The value of the tag key.
